title: Sufficient data to calculate focal length

content.question: Students design an experiment to determine the focal length <math alttext="f" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>f</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> of a converging lens. The students use a lit candle as an object and project its image onto an index card on the other side of the lens. The distance <math alttext="s sub 0" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mrow><msub><mrow><mi>s</mi></mrow><mrow><mi>o</mi></mrow></msub></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math> from the candle to the lens and the distance <math alttext="s sub i" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mrow><msub><mrow><mi>s</mi></mrow><mrow><mi>i</mi></mrow></msub></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math> from the card to the lens are recorded for several values of <math alttext="s sub o" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mrow><msub><mrow><mi>s</mi></mrow><mrow><mi>o</mi></mrow></msub></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math>. Are these data sufficient to calculate <math alttext="f" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>f</mi></mrow></mstyle></math>, and why or why not?

choices.label: No, because the magnification must also be measured for each value of <math alttext="s sub o" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mrow><msub><mrow><mi>s</mi></mrow><mrow><mi>o</mi></mrow></msub></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math>.

No, because <math alttext="f" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>f</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> will be different for each value of <math alttext="s sub o" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mrow><msub><mrow><mi>s</mi></mrow><mrow><mi>o</mi></mrow></msub></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math>.

Yes, because <math alttext="1 over s sub i" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mfrac><mrow><mn>1</mn></mrow><mrow><msub><mrow><mi>s</mi></mrow><mrow><mi>i</mi></mrow></msub></mrow></mfrac></mrow></mstyle></math> can be plotted as function of <math alttext="1 over s sub o" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mfrac><mrow><mn>1</mn></mrow><mrow><msub><mrow><mi>s</mi></mrow><mrow><mi>o</mi></mrow></msub></mrow></mfrac></mrow></mstyle></math> and the <math alttext="y" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>y</mi></mrow></mstyle></math>-intercept used to calculate <math alttext="f" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>f</mi></mrow></mstyle></math>.

Yes, because <math alttext="1 over s sub i" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mfrac><mrow><mn>1</mn></mrow><mrow><msub><mrow><mi>s</mi></mrow><mrow><mi>i</mi></mrow></msub></mrow></mfrac></mrow></mstyle></math> can be plotted as function of <math alttext="1 over s sub o" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mfrac><mrow><mn>1</mn></mrow><mrow><msub><mrow><mi>s</mi></mrow><mrow><mi>o</mi></mrow></msub></mrow></mfrac></mrow></mstyle></math> and the slope can be used to calculate <math alttext="f" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>f</mi></mrow></mstyle></math>.

content.answer: Yes, because <math alttext="1 over s sub i" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mfrac><mrow><mn>1</mn></mrow><mrow><msub><mrow><mi>s</mi></mrow><mrow><mi>i</mi></mrow></msub></mrow></mfrac></mrow></mstyle></math> can be plotted as function of <math alttext="1 over s sub o" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mfrac><mrow><mn>1</mn></mrow><mrow><msub><mrow><mi>s</mi></mrow><mrow><mi>o</mi></mrow></msub></mrow></mfrac></mrow></mstyle></math> and the <math alttext="y" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>y</mi></mrow></mstyle></math>-intercept used to calculate <math alttext="f" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>f</mi></mrow></mstyle></math>.
